description.narrative: Global Water Partnership Organisation, GWPO, är en mellanstatlig organisation etablerad 1996. Sverige är en av stiftarna samt finansiär av organisationen, både i form av värdlandsavtal med regeringen, samt ett kärnstöd sedan etableringen av GWPO och regionala stöd, främst i MENA regionen. GWPO är den juridiska person som Sida har avtal med och som är formellt ansvarig för samarbetet, och som anställer sekretariatets personal mm. Global Water Partnership, GWP, är det internationella nätverk med 13 regionala vattenpartnerskap (RWP) och 85 Nationella vattenpartnerskap CWP), som omfattar ca 3000 partnerorganisationer i 178 länder, som finansieras och får sin övergripande styrning via GWPO. Sidas bidrag kommer att uppgå till ca 10 % av den beräknade totala finansieringen av GWPO under perioden. GWP förespråkar en integrerad strategi för förvaltning av vattenresurser (Integrated Water Resources Management, IWRM) för att främja hållbar vattenförvaltning genom ett nätverk av globala, regionala och nationella medlemmar. GWPs klimatrelaterade vattenarbete inom Water, Climate and Development Programme (WACDEP) speciellt i Afrika syftar till att integrera vattensäkerhet och klimatresiliens i utvecklingsplaneringen, och stödjer länder i att anpassa sig till nya klimatförhållanden genom ökade investeringar i vattensäkerhet. Man har aktiviteter i åtta länder, fyra gränsöverskridande avrinningsområden bland andra Burkina Faso, Burundi, Moçambique, Rwanda, och Zimbabwe; Lake Chad Basin och Volta Basin.

Global Water Partnership Organization, GWPO, is an intergovernmental organization established in 1996. Sweden is one of the founders and a financier of the organization, both in the form of a host country agreement with the Government, as well as a core support since the establishment of GWPO and regional cooperation, mainly in the MENA region. GWPO is the legal entity that Sida has agreements with and who is formally responsible for cooperation, and employing staff of the Secretariat mm. Global Water Partnership, GWP, the international network of 13 Regional Water Partnership (RWP) and 85 National Water Partnership CWP), which covers approximately 3,000 partners in 178 countries, funded and receives its overall control via GWPO. Sida's contribution will amount to about 10% of the estimated total funding of GWPO under the period. GWP advocates an integrated approach to water resources management (Integrated Water Resources Management, IWRM) to promote sustainable water through a network of global, regional and national members. GWPs climate-related water work in Water, Climate and Development Programme (WACDEP) especially in Africa aims to integrate water security and climate resilience in development planning, and supports countries to adapt to new climate conditions through increased investment in water safety. It has activities in eight countries, four trans boundary river basins including Burkina Faso, Burundi, Mozambique, Rwanda, and Zimbabwe; Lake Chad Basin and the Volta Basin.

The Global Water Partnership (GWP) is a multi-stakeholder action network and intergovernmental organisation dedicated to working with countries towards the equitable, sustainable and efficient management of water resources. GWP is made up of 3000 plus partner organisations in over 180 countries.
GWPs vision is a water secure world. To realise this vision GWP supports countries to advance governance and management of water resources for sustainable and equitable development. This is done by promoting Integrated Water Resources Management (IWRM), a cross-sectorial policy approach, designed to replace the traditional, fragmented approach that has led to poor services and unsustainable resource use. As a means to achieving long-term impact towards water security, GWP seeks to influence water governance through the promotion of Integrated Water Resources Management principles. Policy development, strategic planning, legislative change, investment planning and transboundary agreements are examples of processes where GWP actively contributes at the global, regional, national and subnational levels.
Increased climate resilience among vulnerable communities, reduced incidences of water borne disease and protection of fragile ecosystems are examples of benefits of strengthened water governance.
According to the GWP theory of change, sustainable impact is achieved through improvements in governance structures, planning frameworks, institutional capacity and management instruments. By embedding water security into governance processes such as development planning, institutional reform, legislation, etc. an enabling environment is created through which water sensitive investments are made.
GWP therefore aims to influence governance processes by working with actors at all levels to instigate improvements in identified change areas which in the water governance spectrum. Such influence typically manifests itself through key water governance outcomes such as a revised water policy, a new national climate change adaptation plan, a restructured institution, the introduction of a tariff structure, etc.
The work of GWP is applicable to all water-related Sustainable Development Goals and their targets

description.narrative: At the end of 2020, the GWP Network had 13 Regional Water Partnerships (RWPs), 68 Country Water Partnerships (CWPs), and 3,324 Partners located in 183 countries. The work of GWP is applicable to all water-related SDGs and their targets. This work is guided by the principles of integrated water resources management and fully aligned with measuring progress towards SDG 6, indicator 6.5.1: degree of implementation of IWRM. GWP results mostly delivers to strategy goal 1: Strengthened protection and rehabilitation, as well as sustainable management and use of marine, coastal and freshwater ecosystems, biodiversity, natural resources, and ecosystem services. (80%) and to less extent to strategy goal 2: Cleaner water and oceans, reduced emissions of pollutants and reduced littering.(10 %) and: Reduced vulnerability of people living in poverty as well as increased resilience to manage climate change and natural disasters. 10% Intergrated water resource management is a hollistic approch in nature, hence the activitites and results delivers towards several goals. Key results in 2020 include (from annual narrative report 2020): In total 42 key water governance outcomes were influenced by GWP activities including: 14 New local, national and regional river basin policies, plans and strategies. 17 Investment plans, strategies and budget commitments and 5 River basin agreements. Investments worth around 120 million Euro can be linked to GWP´s work. Strategy goal 1: Strengthened protection and rehabilitation, as well as sustainable management and use of marine, coastal and freshwater ecosystems, biodiversity, natural resources, and ecosystem services. To less extent Goal 2 Cleaner water and oceans, reduced emissions of pollutants and reduced littering (activities on waste water). Building on discussions over several years, in 2020 the riparian countries of the Drin river basin (Albania, Greece, Kosovo, Montenegro, and North Macedonia) jointly developed and signed a strategic programme outlining more than 100 actions to overcome obstacles and promote sustainable water resources development. The Drin project implementation strategy conducted six demonstration activities: Lake Ohrid Watershed Management Plan; Integrated modelling tool/Wastewater treatment options in the Shkodra city area; Assessing the feasibility of applying micro-insurance schemes in flood prone area; Production of fire-briquettes using excess biomass from Skadar/Shkoder Lake; Constructed Wetland in Karmovik; Design and testing of a multi-purpose (transboundary) groundwater monitoring network at Skadar/Shkoder Lake. In Southern Africa, GWP helped to mobilise 5 million Euro from the Global Environment Facility for a new project on managing competing water uses and protecting ecosystems in the Buzi, Pungwe, and Save river basins, which are shared by Mozambique and Zimbabwe. One of the outcomes is Flood and drought warning and mitigation which delivers towards the strategy goal for Reduced vulnerability of people living in poverty as well as increased resilience to manage climate change and natural disasters. Almost 60 knowledge products was produced by GWP. Such as the SDG 6 IWRM Stage 1 Support Package. Produced to support the second round of reporting on SDG indicator 6.5.1 in 2020 and the SDG IWRM Support Programme mini-site. The SDG 6 IWRM Support Programme assists governments in designing their national responses to the implementation of integrated water resources management, as measured by SDG indicator 6.5.1. The Support Programme is administered by GWP and operated in partnership with the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), UNEP, DHI Centre, and Cap-Net. GWP also helped to finalise six Stage 2 IWRM Action Plans, and supported implementation of another seven Stage 3 activities. The work included assisting India, Kyrgyzstan, Laos, Nicaragua, Tajikistan, and Turkmenistan to report on IWRM implementation for the first time. Stage 3 activities in Kazakhstan have encouraged the government to integrate the new IWRM Action Plan with the existing State 2030 Water Management Programme. Kazakhstan has also developed a new version of its Ecological Code, which embraces the recommendations of the IWRM Action Plan. GWP has helped to secure financing of US$0.5–1 million from the national treasury to implement actions identified in Kenya’s IWRM Action Plan. Around 200,000 US dollars was leveraged in UNDP funding for new Stage 3 projects in Armenia and Vietnam. In 2020 GWP and the Global Environment Facility International Waters Learning Exchange and Resource Network developed a massive open online course (MOOC), Governance for Transboundary Freshwater Security. As of April 2021, more than 2,000 learners from 145 countries have participated. In 2020, GWP provided support on government requests to 61 countries to report on the status of SDG indicator 6.5.1. This support included hosting multi-stakeholder consultation workshops and providing guidance materials in different languages. Strategy goal: Reduced vulnerability of people living in poverty as well as increased resilience to manage climate change and natural disasters. In 2019, GWP was appointed as a delivery partner by the Green Climate Fund (GCF). In 2020, GWP received formal requests for support from nine countries (Burundi, Central African Republic, Eswatini, Libya, Montenegro, Somalia, Sri Lanka, Sudan, and Zambia). The goal of these proposals is to further develop and implement national climate resilience commitments, including National Adaptation Plans (NAPs) and Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs), in line with the Paris Agreement. The total value of GCF projects currently in the pipeline exceeds 25 million Euros. GWP is playing an increasing role in incorporating the topic of water management into the global debate on disaster risk reduction. In 2020, this included providing input to the High-Level Experts and Leaders Panel on Water and Disasters (HELP) Draft Principles to Address Water-related Disaster Risk Reduction under the Covid-19 Pandemic. GWP has mobilised around 17.5 million Euros for climate, transboundary and other inititatives. Gender equality (cross-cutting issue): In April 2020, GWP launched the Continental Africa Water Investment Support Programme on water, climate, development, and gender. This promotes a gender transformative approach to development, which means ensuring gender equality becomes a cornerstone in all planning, decision-making, and institutional development towards climate-resilient water management. Commected to GWP's organisational work: In 2020, GWP launched the Network strengthening initiative to support implementation of the new Strategy. The Strengthening Regional Operational Network Growth (StRONG) programme which aims to enhance the capacity of the Regional and Country Water Partnerships to deliver results. Covid-19 GWP provided guidance to the network on where to focus attention under the rapidly changing circumstances via an internal paper entitled GWP Positioning in a COVID-19 World. GWP supported regional assessments of the impact of COVID-19 on the water sector; for example, working with the Southern African Development Community and Regional Technical Committee in the Caribbean.Savings on travel were reallocated to Network-strengthening activities.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
